For example, just for example, if your restaurant smells great from the outside, and then all the food sucks, your customers are going to walk away quite disappointed.  Like they've been misled.  They will wander in off the street, following their noses like some kind of cartoon dog (Coooooooooooookie Criiiiiiiisssspppp!), then order some delicious looking food, sit down, and find out IT HAS ALL BEEN ONE BIG LIE, YOU SCAMMING SONNAMABITCH!  The food, they will find, is rubbery and tasteless.  The noodles are limp and ineffective, like Bob Dole's wang.  The BBQ pork is only slightly more chewy than the rubber newspaper dog toy sold at PetsMart.

And then, the customer will walk away, shaking his or her head, disappointed and deflated, like a scorned 17-year-old boy on prom night.

I loved you, you bitch!
author: Ben P.

description:
I've always liked this place - one of the waitresses used to work at U-Lee, the famous potstickers-the-size-of-your-fist place on Hyde, back in the early '90s. Anyone remember it? When I first used to go to U-Lee she was hugely pregnant. Recently I was in the Golden Horse and asked about her family. She told me her kid just graduated from UC Davis. Yes, I felt this old.

Anyway, their snapper with black bean sauce is one of my favorite dishes. Whenever I order anything else I'm usually pretty happy. A totally reliable Chinese restaurant where you can get a square meal for cheap.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
REDISCOVERY! 
Golden Horse has been around the neighborhood a long time +20 years but my visit there last night was positive from several aspects.
First, get over the tough parking in the area and if all fails you can always risk the underground parking at Cala's across the street.

Ok - Aspect #1 - clean upgraded look, apparently, new owners since 2 yrs have completely remodeled the dining room.  I mean raising the ceiling height and adding crown molding - that is unheard of detailing from a chinese restaurant.  Although the room is not that expansive, you don't feel 'crowded'.  This will give you a clue into Aspect #3.

Aspect #2 - Excellent menu selections from typical to the more exotic jellyfish, quail.  However, go to the inside back cover of the menu and choose from 4 preset family dinners ranging from $25.80 - $56.80 and you can't make a mistake here...the portions are not so puny that you have to request double portions.  We attended after a memorial and had two tables and our table had 5 adults and one teenager and we still boxed up 3 takeaways with leftovers.  See below for the family menu we selected.

Aspect #3 - One would think and assume that at $32.80 for 6 perfectly cooked and seasoned dishes ($5.47 per dish), it would be portioned for a party of 3 but as I stated in #2, they do not do that.  Plus, my comment about their detailing of the dining room extends to their detailing of the way the food is actually presented on each dish.  I would be easier to tip the wok of perfectly cooked vegetables onto a plate and ring the bell to serve, but they actually took the time to arrange the greens in a circular pattern and the seafood (prawns, squid & mushrooms) add to the overall color of the dish.  Each dish showed the same level of detailing which only adds to an overall positive experience - Bravo!

$32.80 gives you 
Sliced pork, salted egg w/ mustard green soup - Very tasty and not too salty.

Spicy salt baked spareribs - similar to salt pepper pork chops, again not over seasoned.

Double seafood with tender greens = very good presentation

Beef stew and tofu in a clay pot = very yummy and temperature hot

Pan fried flounder = crispy and golden, no hint of oil that has 10,000 hours of work.

Chinese broccoli (guy lon) with oyster sauce = tender and deep green

I wasn't disappointed that a light dessert did not come with this dinner.

Service was excellent and friendly.  

Check Golden Horse out especially if you haven't been there in the past two years.
author: Randall F.

description:
Golden Horse is the workhorse of my favorite Chinese restaurants- reliable, economical, and conveniently located in my hood and across from Cala.  I'm half Chinese from a Chinese restaurant-owning family so my tastes are Americanized (and then some) but I still know the good stuff when I see it.  

Half the time what I order isn't on the menu, but like most Chinese places, they're great about making whatever dish you want.  GH has great scallops.  Very fresh and high quality.  Their beef, while still quintessentially Chinese restaurant-esuqe, is less fatty and gristly than most other places.  I love their shrimp dishes.  Their kung-pao shrimp is so tasty that despite its not being nearly spicy enough, and its having peanuts and bell peppers which I don't like, I order it again and again.  I love their bbq pork won ton soup, especially when I'm not feeling so hot.

The only thing I've really disliked there was their sesame chicken.  I know I should know better and I always cringe when ordering it anywhere, but I LOVE the syrupy fried chicken dish.  That is, I love it when it's actually fried chicken and not disgusting fried bits of God-knows-what as it is at Golden Horse.  I have a theory that Chinese places use dishes like sesame chicken as both a litmus test to weed out the idiots who should be eating at Panda Express and as a way to make money deep frying whatever scraps are kicking 'round the kitchen and serving it to said idiots.  Thankfully, I enjoyed dozens of other dishes before ordering the sesame chicken, so I recognized it for the aberration it was.
author: Lauren C.

description: Highly recommend the wonton soup and pork spring rolls. This place is clean and fast, and you get tea upon sitting :)
author: Eugenia B.
M.S. C.

description: Definitely one of the busiest restaurants during Christmas and New Years. Came here with my family and saw this huge line just waiting to be sat. Servers told me 30mins to an hour but they were able to turn tables very quickly and seat me and my family of 8. They were definitely rushing everything but was able to get our food out even with the busy rush. We had the family set course on the back on the menu. Everything on it was good. My favorite had to be the honey walnut shrimp. Best honey walnut shrimp I had in the whole city.
author: Ace W.

description: They give you tons of  food but none of it tasted all that great. Not horrific, just kind of boring. So boring in fact that I cannot remember what I ordered.
author: David M.

description:
Finally, my first review on yelp.  Been reading reviews for a year now, and I figure I'll give back to the community that has taught me so much about the city I now live in.  

Golden Horse is reasonably priced.  I believe around $6-$8 for typical fried rice and noodle plates, more for seafood entrees, but it doesn't go above $13 or so unless it's got the expensive stuff in it.  Usually the neighborhood is terrible for parking (Nob Hill), but park in the Cala across the street, and sneak out so they don't know you're not a paying customer.  I doubt they'll care much since since they're getting demolished soon to make way for a Whole Foods with luxury condos above.  

The food is solid.  Try the rock cod clay pot and won ton soup.  I forget what it's called but it's not the typical won ton soup.  Peep the menu and you'll see what I mean.  It's deep fried won tons in the soup so it creates a soggy soupy delictable mix.


I feel pretty proud of my first review.


Peep the method, check it correct it...
author: Law C.

description: Pretty basic chinese food, not the best not the worst.  The portions are huge which is nice.
author: Morgan C.

description: This place is OK. The prices are right and the food seems authentic, and menu varying, but the options aren't all consolidated, and some of the food I've had has been a little too offbeat for my tastes, which says a lot for someone who has eaten sheep's knuckles and mapani worms. Order at your own risk. Their family meal deals are superb and this place came at the high recommendation of a Chinese man in the know...
author: Andrew K.

description:
Called in an order "To Go" this afternoon.

After giving my order, I asked how much that would cost.  The woman's reply was (and I quote) , "I don't know yet, we're busy.  You come in and pick it up."  Then, before I could respond, or ask if she wanted my name for the order, I was hung up on without another word.

Clearly this place has so much business that they don't need mine, and will not be receiving it.
author: Jessie B.

description:
I came here on Chinese New Years eve, which was a mistake because the restaurant was PACKED. First of all, the restaurant was pretty small to begin with, and add about 50 people and you have yourself a madhouse. 

To address a couple of things mentioned by the previous reviews. The place is not clean....at all. The table tops were greasy. The plates still had food stain on them. The tea cups felt oily too.

The service was horrible even by chinese restaurant standards. I understand it was Chinese new years, but even after the crowds cleared out, we didn't get our check for 15 minutes after telling them TWICE that we wanted to pay.

The food wasn't that great. Most of their recommended dishes are fried and did not taste very fresh.

The only redeeming point is the price. An entree was about 7 dollars, which is pretty cheap.
author: Daniel C.

description:
UPDATE:

The health inspector has rated this place a 63.  NOT GOOD.  Im so sad to think ive been enjoying cockroches, all the time thinking they were potstickers :(

I hate to do it, but I gotta take away three of the four stars! I mean if youre gonna serve food people..... com'on!!!!! 


It only took me 3 short years to discover this restaurant, and a friend had to tell me about it (I know, I'm slow).  

The food consistently is what you would expect from a high end Chinese restaurant.  The veggie fried rice is delicious and not overly saturated with grease and full of enough green things to keep "the girl" (my girlfriend) happy.  The Mongolian beef has just the right level of heat, and I cant get enough of their pork pot-stickers.  You wont be disappointed with anything on the menu.

The dining room is comfortable, and if you have the right seat you can watch the crabs and lobsters peer through their aquarium wondering why that man over there is eating their friend. :D

The price is perfect and the family that run the restaurant is always very happy to see you.  A great middle of the week stop.
author: Chris G.

description:
The ladies that work here can take awhile to warm up to you but once they know you, they are very sweet.  I stop by here twice a week for "to-go".

Pretty authentic Chinese food like the dishes you find in Chinatown.  I love their salt & pepper fried fish and boneless steam chicken w/ ham, mushroom & Chinese greens.
author: Kate L.

description: For once, I came here for lunch rather than dinner and loved the change.  I ordered the House Special which was very unique but a combination of all my favorite foods.  Chow fun AND chow mein noodles (perfect because I couldn't decide what kind to order) chicken, pork, and shrimp/calamari (wow, the variety!!), baby corn (loved it since..well, since I was a baby!!), mushrooms (#1 favorite food), bamboo shoots and carrots!  Come on, that's like the world's best combination.  The portion was massive for only $6 smthg AND came with soup!!  It was a refreshing tofu, dropped egg, and mushrooms (!!) soup that was delicious all on its own.  The fortune cookie was on the stale side, but I'm not complaining since I was so full!! Thumbs up for my favorite Chinese restaurant!
author: Nicole G.

description:
Didn't realize so many others viewed Golden Horse so highly. It's good to know I'm not the only one who enjoys the decently priced, incredibly tasty food they offer.

This is one the spots my friends and I usually gather at on Wednesday nights when we dine out, and it's by far the one we've been to most often. The Cantonese style dishes they offer are made well, and some dishes stand out more than others -- my friends in particular like the BBQ spareribs and the dao mew (snow pea leaves with garlic). Their soup warms me up on cold nights.

The staff is actually quite friendly and knows us by now, and they usually usher us to one of the big tables in the back area. Considering we're usually kind of loud (and probably obnoxious, haha) they're pretty patient with us. Always a plus.

Not much to say about the decor; Golden Horse looks like every other mid-scale Chinese restaurant I've been to in San Francisco, and it's smaller than some. Ultimately though it's never really affected my judgment of the place. After all, there's that old saying about books and covers and blah, blah, blah... you know the rest.

If you're in the area and looking for some scrumptious Chinese food -- in San Francisco, how can you NOT find any? -- then Golden Horse is worth checking out.
author: Will C.

description:
If you're looking for a quick chinese fix this is your place.  the staff is friendly and nice and its a good spot to hit when you're near the hospital or near the bars.  golden horse does chinese food right and thats coming from a chinese kid who loves chinese food!

the price is right and the food is just right on the money when it comes to variety and taste... grab a cold beer with the order to make it a complete meal...
author: Harry H.

description:
Yo man, whenever I see people of the ethnicity eating in that restaurant, I presume it's authentic, and this place is loaded with Chinese peeps.  Recently renovated, great food and wow dinner for 3 tonight for $22.00.  
My forturne: Do not avoid what you know to be right...
in bed?
author: Moi S.

description:
SALT AND PEPPER CHICKEN WINGS!!MUST HAVE!!

So far, I've only been here twice, both times at lunch for the rice plates.
 
-The eggplant rice plate was delicious. 
-Kungpoa chicken was not as good(spicy) as I have imagined it to be. 
-Mongolian beef was generic (nothing more than beef with hoisin sauce). 
-The Singaporean curry rice noodle was alright..I wouldn't want to try it again since I've eaten tastier elsewhere. 
-Beef fried rice: Ok (not the best).

One thing I love about the place is the old-fasioned teacups and plates. 
Service: Not the best, but acceptable.

* Their health review score was an 83! How?, I do not know. The place seemed pretty clean to me.( At least the dining area)
author: Edward C.

description:
Everyone had their favorite Chinese restaurant in their hood....right?  Well  you can't beat Golden Horse if you live in the area..  The owners are really nice and the owner normally delivers our food when we order deliver!   Try the live Dungeness crab which is normally priced at $14.95, it is really awesome.  
Sure they may not bring the check right away as I read in some of the other reviews, but remember this ain't fine dining.  Just flag them down and ask for the darn check.
If you live in the Nob Hill area this place is a must for those lazy nights!
author: John M.

description: The food is great. Service was good. We were there CNY and it was quite busy but they were very nice and efficient. The price was excellent. Place was simple but clean. A little noisy and parking a little difficult. Right in front of Trader Joe's.
author: E B.

description:
So my bro calls me at around 11:30 asking me what time i take lunch. I told him I pretty much can go at any time and why the hell would he care? He lives in Sacramento so I knew he wasn't calling for lunch.  But he WAS!  What a wonderful surprise. He was just stopping by into the city to have lunch to satisfy his craving for San Francisco Chinese food so he chose this place since it was really close to my work.

I was a little hesitant to go to this restaurant because I am so used to eating at Bamboo Restaurant on Pine and California.  But upon tasting the food - Bamboo has got nothing on this place (I may just have to edit my review on Bamboo).  It may not be as nice inside as Bamboo (Golden Horse reminds me more of a shower room than a restuarant) but the food was pretty damn good.  Everything was tasty and nothing was doused with too much soy sauce or salt.  The hot and spicy spare ribs is a must try.
author: Anne M.

description:
This place serves slightly above-average Chinese food at really low prices, but the restaurant is kind of dingy and dirty. The bathrooms are also really gross, which, unfortunately, is typical of most Chinese restaurants in the city.

I am not a fan out eating Chinese food out simply because it always tastes too greasy or salty to me, but my very authentically Chinese parents and grandparents enjoyed our meal here, so the food must be pretty good. If you're in the neighborhood and craving cheap Chinese, Golden Horse is not a bad choice, but it is not worth it to go out of the way to eat here.
author: Karen L.

description:
Had my BDAY Banquet here and loved it! We had a 10 course meal for $118 - they had a great special @ this time. There were 10 of us gals, so if there were 1 or 2 more gals, it would have been enough. The round could fit about 11 ppl. 

Lots of seafood and some of my fav's. They even served duck in bun, seafood soup, pork ribs, crab, and a number of other items (totaling 11 items). The owners are really nice and accommodating.

My aunt recommended this place because she is sensitive to MSG, and they do not use that here. It's a small restaurant but cute. Hard to find parking, but worth it.
author: M M.

description: This place has been here for years, we used to come all the time for large family dinners. Some of their best dishes were fried calamari and black bean crab. The crab was the best I have ever had, tasty and hot. I'm guessing the cooks have changed so the food may not be as good as it was. The dining area is real dated, nice but it has seen better days. Good luck on finding a parking space within two blocks, cuz St. Francis is right down the block and Cala across the street, so spaces are premium around there. This is a hole-in-the wall place, with about a 50 person capacity.  Cleanliness is questionable.
author: Larry G.

description: This place is right down the street from my apartment and I see asians in the restaurant often, so I thought it might be worth a try.  I was mistaken.  The food here is no good.  Its like they have a set of premade ingredients and then they mix them up with a different base to make all their dished.  I ordered 3 dishes, and they all basically came out with the same ingredients.  One of the dishes was hot and sour soup and another was shanghai noodles.  It's pretty questionable if your using the same ingredients for these two dishes, since they're quite different.  Unsurprisingly, I haven't been back.
author: Elsa H.

description: This place is in my neighborhood. It's so cheap, and has the best sweet & sour pork in town. I don't eat sweet & sour pork very often but have a craving for it once in a very while. Don't get it from the lunch counter but order it from the kitchen. You need to eat it in the restaurant also otherwise it's no good. It's unhealthy but so yummy!! Closest thing you could get of "Subuta" of Japanese influenced Chinese dish in Japan.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
Love this place -- it's not your overly seasoned/super greasy Chinese takeout from the corner.

It's only a few blocks away from home and I come here whenever I have a hankering for Chinese food.  Good Cantonese-style food at great prices.  I love their crispy fried chicken, sauteed flounder, and their chow meins (not sure which ones I've had but I remember enjoying them all).
author: Guava C.

description:
I know there must be at least 1,000 Chinese restaurants in the City, but my buddy lives near by Hyde so we came here. And so far, it's my favorite of the few that I have been to. 

The service was fast and friendly (the knew my friend Mark rather well, brought him his "regular" with out even needing to ask him). The food was delicious.  While not that close to my house, I could see myself coming back here for sure if I'm in the area.
author: Matthew S.

description:
We are Dragon Well devotees, but sadly they don't deliver, so we've been on a quest for a good Chinese delivery spot in the area. I had high hopes for this place after reading the reviews.  (To be fair, I'm still not entirely convinced that my call to Golden Horse wasn't hijacked by someone pawning off left-overs from St. Francis hospital. And there was a dog barking in the background while the woman took my order. Really?!)  

The wonton soup was completely inedible. The broth tasted like dirty dishwater, the wontons were gross, it was just bad, bad, bad. Then there was some scallop mystery meat thing drenched in pepper, but unfortunately not enough pepper to mask the awful taste of the "beef." The moo shu pork was tasteless (which at that point, was an improvement over the first two). The only thing that was okay - not great, not really good, but a solid okay - was the shrimp in lobster sauce.  It pushed them up to 1.5 stars overall, but I couldn't bring myself to give them 2. 

Still scratching my head at why people like this place so much but not inclined to give it another go. The quest continues...
author: Maggie Z.

description: BBQ Pork Won Ton Soup is the best. Spent months looking for won ton soup that reminded me of what I used to get in NYC. Turns out it doesn't really exist in San Fran but this place comes the closest. Remainder of menu is hit or miss but overall is great for takeout.  Another hidden gem is the fresh shrimp won ton soup, the broth is excellent but be aware it is very simple.... Broth and wontons only.
author: Matthew S.

description: I LOVED the roast duck soup.  Excellent price, amazing portion, meat falling off the bones, no complaints here. Was happy to step out of the way of crack heads asking me for a lite as they extend their pipe in my direction to grab a bite here. ;)
author: Zanna o.

description: Had the Kong Pao chicken the other day with pork fried rice. Have to say it was pretty darn good. I'd recommend this place.
author: Paul F.

description: Golden Horse..I've been coming here since I was I think 10 years old and i'm 21 turning 22 now and I still come here for Chinese New Years and for my Grandma's birthday! The food has always been good just like I remembered when I was a child! I love the buns with the peking duck, the crab the fried fish and especially the soup! =) I never get tired of coming here! It gets really really crowded on the weekend..so if you have a big group make sure to make reservations!
author: Heather C.

description: Pretty darn tasty, this place is.  They do a great job of not trying to be too fancy, and just serve up some good, not-too-greasy chinese food that makes you fell like home.  Even for a good ol' honky like myself.  And I know it might be a little racist to say it, but I feel greatly encouraged to try a new Chinese place and the only white people in the place are myself and the person I'm with.
author: Ian M.

description: Mongolian Beef lunch is good. Very D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S. The price is cheap around $5. Soup is included. Yummy.
author: mc a.

description: Really delicious and creative Chinese food - I was not in the mood for lomain, fried rice, or any of the usuals, but this restaurant has "clay pots" that come sizzling to your table, all kinds of wontons, and a ton of other choices.  I had dumplings, an egg roll and FANTASTIC beef satay with vermicelli.  I will definitely be back here again after drinking in North Beach ;)
author: Laura W.

description: Decent cheap chinese food, not great, not bad. I got Won Ton soup, and was slightly disappointed, the broth seemed to be a little watered down. I also got he szechuan chicken, which could have been spicier, but threw a little chili sauce on and it was fine.
author: Kelly L.

description:
So they have made some changes and their Health Score is now up to 83!
I have never been disappointed by their food or service so Golden Horse is back on my list of places I know aren't exactly the cleanest but I am willing to take my chances. 
It doesn't hurt that they are half a block from my door and I loooove Cantonese food.
author: JA C.

description: i've been coming to this spot for years with my family. and i must say it has always been consistently awesome. the waitstaff  recognize us as regulars and are always friendly and quick! and you know the food is good when the place is full of chinese people chowing down. not to mention the prices are super cheap!
author: Katie M.

description: All the food is superb. I love their BBQ Pork Won Ton Soup, Pot Stickers and Egg Rolls. No skimping on the food. The BBQ Pork Won Ton Soup has about 20 pieces of BBQ Pork in it!
author: Walter W.

description: This place is soooo good.  The service is pretty ok, but they try their best.  The reason I gave 4 out of 5 stars is because one time, I saw the waitress drop the fortune cookies on the floor and picked it back up to put it into the same can and served it to customers.  I never eat the fortune cookies there, but they have great lunch specials, and they are very nice to all customers.  The food is great.  $5 for a 2-item lunch.  So much cheaper than Panda Express if u were to get chinese food from there. :)
author: Amy A.

description: This restaurant just reopened after a month of renovations.  The new place is cleaner and better decorated.  Not exactly a gourmet restaurant but a good, authentic place.  You can also order dishes that aren't on the menu (like mustard greens).  I especially enjoy their lychee fried fish and their shrimp egg foo yung.
author: Mahogany G.

description: Good price. Consistent delivery of food. Consistent taste over a broad range of menu items. Eat there frequently when feeling in the mood for chinese food. Many employees at the hospital nearby order take out and carryout and seem to like the food and service.
author: Patrick R.

description: Whenever I see a Chinese food place packed with locals, I know its good.  The food here is great, and the portions! Geez! They must think people have stomachs the size of Buddha's!  The service, though not necessarily warm, was brisk and efficient.  The restaurant was the biggest drawback: it was very very dirty and unwelcoming.  Overall, I give it props because the tasty dishes and price point were just what I needed!
author: Tova S.

description: My family no longer like to order to go from here.  It doesn't taste as good as it use to be.
author: Anna S.

description: I eat here so often they know what to bring to my table before I even order.  Because of that I can only say they have excellent service.  But I have been going here sometimes weekly for over 5 years.  Is it the best Chinese Food in SF?  I honestly have no idea.  But they are very pleasant and inexpensively priced.  I would recommend this restaurant to anyone.  You can't beat the price of their lunch buffet.
author: Tommy B.

description: This place is great...casual and friendly and the food was great!  We enjoyed sauteed shrimp with mixed vegitables and cashew nuts, chicken chow mein, and hot and sour soup.  Everything was tastey and not loaded with salt or overly sauced.  The portions were great and we ate a huge meal and had leftovers for under 30 bucks!  This place is great choice for chinese!
author: Sweet C.

description: I mentioned in the post about Hyde Out that I went there and it was most awesomeness when it comes to Chinese food...and I'm saying it again.  The BF and I went there on a whim after having a drink at Hyde Out.  Our waitress was the only downpoint of the whole experience.  She seemed angry that she was even serving people, exasperated, and just generally annoyed unless she was talking to one of her co-workers.  Whatever, my man and I just laughed about it.  We ordered the Dinner special (the first one) with the two person minimum and that 2 person minimum is a stretch.  The both of us could barely get through half of the chicken chow mien, fried spare ribs, general's chicken, tofu soup and egg rolls.  We had enough to take home and eat for nights.  And our bill? With tip it was around about $30 +/-.  And we spoke with a super sweet man while he boxed up our meal...this place has been around for 15 years.  Yum Yum in your Tum Tum with Bucks left in your wallet (sorry...I know, I know)!
author: Veronica S.

description: this is right around the corner from my apt so it is perfect for those nights i don't want to cook. pretty clean and super fast service. food is not amazing but they've been pretty consistent and they have a pretty good selection of comfort-food type items on the menu (i.e. fried fish with creamed corn and chicken and salted fish fried rice).
author: Rowena M.

description: I tend to go for more spicey asian food but this place was good. It is Cantonese and Mandarin. I went to lunch and had the salt and pepper chicken wings for an appetizer-delicious. I had #188 Shredded chicken fried yee foo noodle. It was a huge plate but a little bland nothing a little soy sauce didn't improve and in fact delicious enough to eat the huge plate. There were a few weird mushrooms on it which I gave to my friend. He said they were bland. My friend had #21 rice plate with sliced cod with greens on rice. He said it was delicious and they give a huge plate with a lot of rice. They also gave us some seaweed shrimp soup with tofu-or at least I saw those things in it. There were a lot of asian people eating here which is usually a good sign. I also was expecting it to be a dive but it is actually a nice place. They also have a express line where  you can pick out food and take out or eat there. I would go back again!
author: Jack B.

description: I've not eat in before.  Bought take out a few times and didn't really like it.  Their food don't taste as original Chinese restaurant.  Plus food portion for a box of take out is not even full in a box.  You can get better salt and pepper ribs at another place, but not here.  I suggest walking down a few more blocks to Chinatown to get much delicious food.
author: YELP U.

description: Been coming here since I've been born.  It's got decent Chinese food that always hits the spot.  Not the most refined food that you've eaten, but it does the simple stuff well: noodles, rice, etc.
author: Ian L.

description: This is my 'standby' for anytime am hungry and don't want to deal with crowds or noise, but also I avoid going there at dinner rush or on holidays.  The food is good, portions are big enough for USA appetites, and prices are great.  The service is sometimes sloppy (as noted by others, especially with soup) but normally fast and easy.
author: Steve P.

description: yum! and they deliver too! My husband and I had to have their food at least once a month. You actually feel good after eating their food, not like other greasy Chinese restaurant. One of the best Chinese restaurant in SF.!
author: alice k.
